tossups.question: Jack Nasar defines the "infill" type of these buildings as occupying a disproportionate amount of physical space. The leading writer on these buildings mandates that dormers should always be evenly spaced and notes that they frequently have secondary masses. That same writer noted that tiny “soul patches” were characteristic of these buildings’ landscaping. Critic James Panero gave these buildings a name that puns on Queen Anne, noting that many of them featured two-story-tall porticos. A website chronicling these buildings highlights spaces like (*) "lawyer foyers" and features made from cast Styrofoam. Kate Wagner created a website named for the "Hell" of these buildings, and was sent a cease-and-desist letter by Zillow in 2017. For 10 points, identify these gaudy suburban homes partially nicknamed for a fast-food company.
tossups.answer: McMansions [or Persian palaces; or garage Mahals; or starter castles; or Hummer houses; or McModerns; accept Queen And buildings before "Queen Anne"; prompt on homes or houses or single-family houses or residences or equivalents]

tossups.question: In 2018, a tribunal in this country gutted most of the power of a popular consumer protection agency called SERNAC. Indigenous protesters in this country set up a rewe ("ray-way") altar in its capital to memorialize the 2018 killing of Camilo Catrillanca. In 1991, the architect of this country's constitution was assassinated by the FPMR while leaving Catholic University; that constitution was amended in the 2000s to remove designated senators, a position held for several years by its de facto dictator. An event called "the (*) explosion" in this country was justified by the slogan, "it's not thirty pesos, it's thirty years," a reference to a metro fare increase. In 2020, voters in this country approved rewriting its constitution, which may soon grant more rights to its native Mapuche people. For 10 points, name this country that has experienced recent unrest in Santiago.
tossups.answer: Chile [or Republic of Chile; or República de Chile]

tossups.question: Marvel's Iron Man films inspired this company to develop holographic technology dubbed Project Jarvis. This company sank 200 million dollars on a branded Sanyo flip phone after its then-president told Steve Jobs that the iPhone was "the dumbest fucking idea I have ever heard." In 2018, this non-newspaper company abolished its ombudsman position, an office once held by Le Anne Schreiber. Mark Shapiro, an executive at this company in the early 2000s, is mocked for hiring Rush Limbaugh in passages from the oral history (*) Those Guys Have All the Fun. This company's carriage fees of around 8 dollars per month are by far the highest in its industry. An employee at this company tweeted that Donald Trump was a "white supremacist" and was reassigned to work at its site The Undefeated. For 10 points, anchor Jemele Hill worked at what Bristol-based cable network, the "worldwide leader in sports?"
tossups.answer: ESPN [or Entertainment and Sports Programming Network; prompt on Disney; prompt on ABC sports]

tossups.question: Panasonic, which has its US headquarters in this city, sponsored new body cams for its police. An insurance company founded in this city in 1875, Prudential, has lent out accountants to help it deal with a 93-million-dollar budget deficit. This city's official historian, Junius Williams, wrote a 2019 biography of Kenneth A. Gibson, the first Black mayor to be elected in the region. A later mayor of this city was chronicled in both the Sundance Channel documentary Brick City and in Street Fight, a film about his 2002 race against Sharpe James. It's not Flint, but this city's (*) Star-Ledger newspaper has chronicled its lead water pipe crisis. A mayor of this city successfully won a senate seat after Frank Lautenberg died of viral pneumonia. Its current mayor is the son of Dutchman author Amiri Baraka. For 10 points, name this New Jersey city whose mayors have included Cory Booker.
tossups.answer: Newark, New Jersey

tossups.question: A 2020 book by Carl T. Bergstrom and Jevin D. West offers tips for interpreting this ethos "in a data-driven world." This ethos involves both human and interactional inquiry per a 2020 book by Chris Heffer that revises Grice's maxims with the TRUST framework. An essay titled for this ethos quotes fatherly advice from Eric Ambler's novel Dirty Story. This ethos titles a book that explicates the miseries of "knowing that one is doing harm" and "not feeling entitled to one's misery," which calls its proliferation a form of "spiritual warfare." This ethos is exhibited by (*) duct tapers, goons, taskmasters, and box tickers in David Graeber's theory of meaningless jobs. Max Black's essay "The Prevalence of Humbug" informed Harry Frankfurt's essay defining this ethos as unconcerned with the truth. For 10 points, identify this vulgar term for worthless, deceptive nonsense that may be "called."
tossups.answer: bullshit [accept equivalents or euphemisms like B.S. or bullcrap or bull$#@&; accept humbug before read; prompt on lies or untruthfulness or insincerity or bluffing or similar answers before read; prompt on meaningless or unnecessary or pointless or similar answers; accept On Bullshit; accept Bullshit Jobs: A Theory; accept Calling Bullshit: The Art of Skepticism in a Data-Driven World; accept All Bullshit and Lies?: Insincerity, Irresponsibility, and the Judgment of Untruthfulness]

tossups.question: Peter Gleick's book on our "obsession" with this type of product opens by describing a much-hated security policy at the 2007 opening of the University of Central Florida football stadium as part of a "war" on this product's closest competitor. It's not a fossil fuel, but American production of this good is concentrated in states with absolute capture laws such as Maine and Texas. A company that paid just 200 dollars in extraction fees in 2017 was allowed to increase its production of this good by 50% in Osceola County, Michigan. The US Forest Service controversially allows (*) Nestlé to produce this product in Southern California, where raw material for it is scarce. In 2017, 20,000 pallets full of this stuff were left on a runway after FEMA provided it, but did not distribute it, to Hurricane Maria victims. For 10 points, name this good sold under brand names like Poland Spring and Aquafina.
tossups.answer: bottled water [or bottled mineral water; or bottled spring water; prompt on water or drinking water or fresh water or potable water; accept Bottled and Sold: The Story Behind Our Obsession with Bottled Water]

tossups.question: One character in this work recalls his father "[looking] like another man, bigger, like a Transformer" as he declares "we will not continue to bare our backs from them to strike us down." Near its end, a parole officer declares that shame rather than "guilt or rage" is what "eats us away until we disappear." A student in this work who plans to attend Albright chastises a friend for dreaming of owning a Dunkin' Donuts franchise. Jessie reveals she had planned to travel to Kabul on the Hippie Trail during (*) Tracey's birthday party in this play. The introduction to Act 2, Scene 6 in this play notes that Beyoncé's "Single Ladies" has just been released. One character in this play, Oscar, is savagely beaten by Chris and Jason for working as a scab. For 10 points, name this play centering on workers at a steel plant in Reading ("redding"), Pennsylvania, by Lynn Nottage.
tossups.answer: Sweat

tossups.question: With Laura A. Rosenwald, this scholar argued that “the camera is not simply a neutral eye” in a law review article on the Rodney King tape. This scholar, a one-time employee in a semiconductor factory, co-authored a book whose chapter “Games and the Cognitive System” argued that Pac-Man required more complex mental models than Breakout. A judge dismissed most of David Corwin’s claims against this psychologist stemming from the 1997 Jane Doe case on (*) child sex abuse. In a 1995 experiment, Pickerell and this author of Mind at Play enlisted family members to compile a journal of events from the subjects' childhood, but they inserted a fictitious experience about being lost in a mall at age 5. For 10 points, name this psychologist who fought the “memory wars” in her book The Myth of Repressed Memory.
tossups.answer: Elizabeth Loftus [or Elizabeth Fishman; accept Geoffrey Loftus, who co-wrote Mind at Play; accept Katherine Ketcham, who co-wrote The Myth of Repressed Memory]

tossups.question: In 2011, a Louis Vuitton store in this city commissioned ash sculptures of Jesus and the Buddha staring at each other. An "Earthquake Scene" features in this city's regular performance piece The House of Dancing Water, which is staged in a purpose-built theater. This city's underworld was once controlled by a gangster known as "Broken Tooth." A hydrofoil fleet helped build the fortune of a man whose SJM firm monopolized this city's most lucrative business for four decades. The large "junket" industry in this city lets tourists skirt a (*) 50,000-dollar limit on taking money out of the country and is conducted in VIP rooms that used to be leased from Stanley Ho. Western companies have invested heavily in hotels along this city's Cotai Strip. Sheldon Adelson made a bet on this city becoming the "Las Vegas of the East." For 10 points, name this Chinese gambling mecca.
tossups.answer: Macau [or Macao] (The SJM is the Sociedade de Turismo e Diversões de Macau.)

tossups.question: A court ruled that one of these policies enacted by Montgomery County, Maryland unfairly targeted the Mirant Corporation. The think tank Near Zero argued that limits on excess allowances didn't constrain one of these policies in California. Janet Yellen signed on to one of these policies named for James A. Baker and George P. Shultz that includes border adjustments and automatic escalations. Oregon Republicans opposed this type of policy by thrice walking out of the legislature. The (*) Steel Transformation Plan was introduced to reduce the burden of one of these policies in Australia; that policy was repealed by the Abbott government in 2014. Canada may soon impose tariffs to protect domestic firms from one of these policies that will be assessed at 170 dollars per ton by 2030. For 10 points, name this type of policy that seeks to put a price on greenhouse gas emissions.
tossups.answer: carbon tax [or cap-and-trade; or carbon pricing; or carbon fee or carbon fee and dividend; accept carbon dividend; prompt on things like emissions tax or tax]

tossups.question: The Switched on Pop episode about this “cheap EDM” song notes that “God’s Plan” by Drake uses the same key modulation technique as it. Alexandra Muller had a mild hit in Germany in 2007 with an a cappella version of this song, while Pete Vigeant has the oldest version of it on YouTube. A version of this song that appeared in Just Dance 2020 liberally borrows from Johnny Only’s (*) "Non-Dismemberment Version." This public domain song likely derives from a chant popular at Christian summer camps inspired by a 1970s blockbuster movie. The most popular version of this song was produced as an English-learning aid by South Korea's Pink Fong and has over 7 billion YouTube views. That video for this song features two children making a variety of hand gestures as they "run away" or "go hunt." For 10 points, name this ubiquitous kids’ song that may derive from JAWS.
tossups.answer: "Baby Shark" [accept "Kleiner Hai"]

tossups.question: This author, who once turned down an offer to model khakis for The Gap, calls herself the "twin" of Uruguayan author Eduardo Galeano. She’s not Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, but this author used the epithet "Never again will a single story be told as though it's the only one" from collaborator John Berger for her breakthrough novel. This author donated the prize money from a 1997 literary award to fight dam construction by funding the group Narmada Bachao Andolan. This critic attacked (*) Gandhi as a "Saint of the Status-Quo" who did not sufficiently renounce the caste system in an essay collected in The Algebra of Infinite Justice. She created a hijra character named Anjum who witnesses a massacre in Gujarat in a novel published 20 years after a debut featuring the Orangedrink Lemondrink Man, who assaults Estha. For 10 points, name this author of The Ministry of Utmost Happiness and The God of Small Things.
tossups.answer: Arundhati Roy [or Suzanna Arundhati Roy]

tossups.question: In a recent book, Geoffrey Cain traces this company's early days running a sugar refinery and its pivotal turn-around in the 1990s when its chairman burned thousands of shoddy products at a factory. In 2020, a labor activist who was fired by this company ended his year-long protest atop a traffic camera tower. Until 2020, this conglomerate was ruled by a chairman who was not seen in public since a 2012 heart attack and who only had a minority stake in the 50 companies that comprise it. This company's (*) Tizen OS has had mild success powering Smart TVs, and it also developed a virtual assistant called Bixby. This company is by far the largest producer of AMOLED screens, and it is also the largest chaebol ("cheh-ball"). For 10 points, name this company that had to recall the explosion-prone Galaxy S7.
tossups.answer: Samsung [or Samsung Group; accept Samsung Electronics; accept Samsung Rising]

tossups.question: This city, the "Queen of Queens, City of Cities" narrates its own story in a 2013 novel by the author of The Travel Notes of a Brunette. President Obama was gifted a new translation of a novel set in this city that features a hypochondriac character who takes a different drug for each of his organs. That novel set in this city begins at the outbreak of World War II and is titled A Mind at Peace. A memoir titled for this city includes a chapter on the engraver Antoine Ignace Melling and features photographs by Ara Güler. That same author used this city as the setting for a historical novel that features both a (*) corpse and a coin as narrators. A fictional institution in this city is compiled from objects like cigarette butts, nutcrackers, and panties by Kemal in The Museum of Innocence. For 10 points, name this city, the setting of My Name is Red by Orhan Pamuk.
tossups.answer: İstanbul [accept Constantinople; accept Istanbullu] (The first clue is about Buket Uzuner. A Mind at Peace is by Ahmet Hamdi.)

tossups.question: Alexander Laban Hinton's Stirling Prize-winning book on why this event took place discusses slogans like "trees in the country, fruit in the town." This event popularized a tradition of eating fried tarantulas. A surveillance system active during this event has often been compared to the modern Seiha phone tapping system. Workers digging a fiber optic cable find artifacts of this event in The Land of the Wandering Souls, whose director recreated it with (*) clay figures in The Missing Picture. An annual "Day of Anger" re-enacts this event, which is the subject of Angelina Jolie’s film First They Killed My Father. In 1998, the "Extraordinary Chambers" tribunal was created to try perpetrators of this event like "Comrade Duch" ("DOO-ik"), who ran the torture camp S-21. For 10 points, what event's overdue reckoning led to the 1998 house arrest of Pol Pot?
tossups.answer: Cambodian genocide [or Génocide cambodgien; accept the Killing Fields; accept anything like the takeover of Cambodia by the Khmer Rouge or Angkar or Communist Party of Cambodia or CPK or Democratic Kampuchea or DK or Kâmpŭchéa Prâcheathippadey or Khmae Kro-hom] (Hinton's book is Why Did They Kill?: Cambodia in the Shadow of Genocide. The PM is Hun Sen. The first director is Rithy Panh.)

tossups.question: The mobile app Cataki is widely used by Brazilians working in this industry, some of whom are known as catadores. It's not the defense industry, but a dispute between Canadian and Filipino firms in this industry led the Philippines to recall its Canadian ambassador in 2019. The US has not ratified this industry's international regulation under the 1989 Basel Convention. Taiwan has instituted an EPR program to reform this industry, making it pay-as-you-go and achieving a record-setting 67% (*) diversion rate in Taipei. It's not transportation, but Operation Sword disrupted the practice of backhauling, whereby this industry cheaply shipped goods on returning container ships to China. Companies in this industry might perform "thermal treatment" with incinerators. For 10 points, name this industry that operates landfills.
tossups.answer: garbage [or waste management; or trash; or recycling; or e-waste; or equivalents; accept landfill diversion before “landfills”]

tossups.question: Industry and country required. We want an answer such as "the Canadian maple syrup industry." A whistleblower in this industry doctored a letter from Angela Merkel to test if Wikileaks filtered documents before publication. A list obtained by Le Monde that documented malfeasance in this industry included people such as David Bowie; that list was nicknamed the "Lagarde List." In 2011, Kweku Adoboli caused huge losses for the largest business in this industry through (*) rogue actions. The oldest business in this industry, Wegelin & Company, was shut down by New York prosecutors in 2012. This industry originated the use of numbered accounts unlinked to names. After the Birkenfeld Disclosure, the government that oversees this industry beefed up secrecy laws to further protect firms like UBS from the IRS. For 10 points, name this industry that helps the rich hide money in a neutral European country.
tossups.answer: Swiss banking industry [or Swiss finance industry; accept anything involving Switzerland and banking or tax evasion or wealth management or investing]

tossups.question: Emmanuel Konde examined this country's wealthy immigrant "Bushfallers," named for a pidgin word for "farm." The neologism "anusocratie" was coined during this country's moral panic over homosexuality, which led to the arrest of Jean-Claude Roger Mbede. In a 2020 Nature paper, Lipson et al. identified "ghost modern" humans using ancient DNA from the Shum Laka rock shelter in this country's Grassfields region, which may be the cradle of the Bantu languages. Floods have swamped this country’s (*) Adamawa-speaking Far North region, which shelters Nigerian refugees from Boko Haram. Since 2017, this country has faced an "Anglophone Crisis" over the breakaway western region of Ambazonia, a former British Mandate first colonized by Germany. This country's economic center is the francophone port of Douala. For 10 points, name this country led since 1982 by Paul Biya from Yaoundé.
tossups.answer: Cameroon [or Republic of Cameroon; or République du Cameroun; or Renndaandi Kamerun; accept Ambazonia or Federal Republic of Ambazonia or Amba Land before read; accept West Cameroon or Southern Cameroons or East Cameroon]

tossups.question: X. Sunney Xiè improved this technique by preparing MALBAC products. An index file guides "demultiplexing" in a form of this technique that splits results into R1 and R2. The ANI statistic can compare results from this technique, which is assessed by metrics like L50 and N50. You might analyze this technique's data with BedTools and SamTools. Data from this technique are often processed with the de novo program SPAdes ("spades"), which adjusts its algorithms for building (*) de Bruijn ("duh brown") graphs to compensate for biases in the multiple displacement amplification used in a single-cell version of this technique that offers high-resolution variant calling. PacBio's high-coverage depth, long-read SMRT ("smart") cells, and the Portable MinION ("MIN-eye-on") from Oxford Nanopore have challenged this technique's industrial domination by Illumina. For 10 points, what technique’s “shotgun” variant let us map the human genome?
tossups.answer: DNA sequencing [or word forms like sequence; accept next-generation sequencing or NGS; accept gene sequencing or genome sequencing; accept single-cell sequencing; accept amplicon sequencing; accept deep sequencing; accept shotgun sequencing; accept genomics or genome assembly; accept sequence alignments, but prompt on alignment by asking "how do you acquire the raw data for alignment?"; prompt on DNA amplification before read by asking "to prepare a sample for what technique?"; accept RNA-sequencing or RNA-seq; accept library preparation]

tossups.question: In the opening tracking shot of a film from this country, the camera shifts in and out of focus as it moves along a boat, showing a number of shirtless men playing cards. In a second film from this country, scenes from 1999 and 2025 are connected by the use of the Pet Shop Boys cover of the Village People song "Go West." In a third film, a diabetic ex-miner from this country pursues corrupt officials with a gigantic shotgun. The original-language title of (*) Still Life, a 2006 film from its "Sixth Generation" movement, was chosen to reflect a play by Bertold Brecht, and employs the "distancing effects" which Brecht noted in this country's acting. The film A Touch of Sin was partially inspired by this country’s Foxconn suicides. For 10 points, name this home country of Jiǎ Zhāngkē ("j’yah jong-KUH").
tossups.answer: China [or People's Republic of China or PRC or Zhōngúo or Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó] (All the films are by Jiǎ Zhāngkē; the second film is Mountains May Depart. The original title of Still Life is Sānxiá Hǎorén, meaning “Good People of the Three Gorges.”)

bonuses.leadin: This man adapted Laura Moriarty's book about Jazz Age star Louise Brooks into the 2019 Michael Engler film The Chaperone. For 10 points each:
answers: Julian Fellowes [or Julian Alexander Kitchener-Fellowes, Baron Fellowes of West Stafford; or The Lord Fellowes of West Stafford] (The film was Gosford Park.)
Downton Abbey
Mary Poppins [accept Mary Poppins Returns]
parts: Identify this man who won an Oscar for Best Original Screenplay for a Robert Altman film centering on the murder of Sir William McCordle at the title country house.
Fellowes is probably best known for this series, which began as a spin-off of Gosford Park and has spawned several memes featuring Maggie Smith's character, the Dowager Countess.
Fellowes also wrote the script for a West End musical adaptation of this film. A sequel to this film featured an elderly Dick Van Dyke singing "Trip a Little Light Fantastic."

bonuses.leadin: Reforms in this country caused a SIM card to drop in price from 250 dollars to 1 dollar and fifty cents in a year, sparking the world's highest rate of new internet users in the last 10 years. For 10 points each:
answers: Myanmar [or Burma; or Republic of the Union of Myanmar; or Myidaunzu Thanmăda Myăma Nainngandaw]

amber [accept blood amber; prompt on fossils] (The discovery was Oculudentavis khaungraae, a bee hummingbird-sized reptile that was incorrectly billed as the tiniest dinosaur ever in a now-retracted Nature paper.)
Aung San Suu Kyi [or Daw Aung San Suu Kyi; or Daw Suu; or Amay Suu; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Identify this country where an “online defamation” law led to the 2020 jailing of three poets from its "Peacock Generation."

David Grimaldi has led a boycott of the “blood” variety of this good, which is obtained from Burmese mines seized by Kachins. In 2016, scholars Lìdá Xíng and Jīngmai K. O’Connor made a noted discovery using some of this resource from a Myanmar market.
It’s been easier to buy amber, jade, and rubies from Myanmar since this 1991 Nobel Peace Prize winner assumed de facto control of the country from its military.

bonuses.leadin: This language's word "sentebibu," or "hundred lives," refers to aloe vera, a cash crop grown by many speakers. For 10 points each:
answers: Papiamento [or Papiamentu]
Dutch [or Nederlands]
merengue [accept merengue típico or merengue cibaeño or perico ripiao; accept merengue estilo yanqui; accept merengue redondo; accept pambiche; accept pri-prí]
parts: Name this Portuguese-based creole often adopted by immigrants working at refineries like Lago Oil. This language may share ancestry with the Cape Verde and Guinea-Bissau creoles, but many of its productive morphemes derive from Spanish.
Papiamento is an official language on the ABC islands Aruba and Curaçao, along with this European language of the country that colonized them and Suriname.

Dutch Antillean tambú music has been displaced by this other Caribbean genre in 2/4 time. Sergio Vargas and Las Chicas del Can are artists in this genre, which Juan Luis Guerra has popularized along with bachata.

bonuses.leadin: The 1991 sonnet collection Butterfly Valley: A Requiem was chosen for this country's "culture canon" in 2006. For 10 points each:
answers: Denmark [or Kingdom of Denmark; or Kongeriget Danmark] (Butterfly Valley was written by Inger Christensen. Karate Chop was written by Dorthe Nors. The show is Borgen.)
Naja Marie Aidt (“ight”)
Greenland [or Kalaallit Nunaat; or Grønland; accept The Greenlanders]
parts: Name this homeland of the author of Mirror, Shoulder, Signal and Karate Chop. The first female prime minister of this European country takes power with the "Moderate Party" in a TV show named for its Baroque Revival governmental palace.
This Danish author of Rock, Paper, Scissors achieved international success with her collection Baboon. She responded to her son's death in the memoir When Death Takes Something from You Give It Back.

Naja Marie Aidt was born on this large island, like the novelist Niviaq Korneliussen and the protagonist of Smilla's Sense of Snow. A Jane Smiley novel set on this island drew on accounts of its Norse colonization from the Saga of Erik the Red.

bonuses.leadin: This country's tourism industry tanked after a local Al-Qaeda affiliate almost shot down a Boeing 757 full of Israeli tourists. For 10 points each:
answers: Kenya [or Republic of Kenya; or Jamhuri ya Kenya]
indoor shopping malls [prompt on shopping centers]
Uganda Railway [accept Uganda Standard Gauge Railway]
parts: Name this country where terrorists simultaneously raided an Israeli-owned hotel in 2002. Organized criminals such as the Mungiki in this country control the brewing of a spirit called changaa.

A decade after the hotel attack, 70 people were killed in an attack on one of these places in Nairobi called Westgate. In the US, many of these retail spaces have been replaced with "lifestyle centers" that copy the aesthetics of town squares.

In 2017, Nairobi was connected to Mombasa by a new China-financed standard gauge railway. The railway runs parallel to this colonial-era narrow-gauge railway, whose construction was plagued by attacks from the “man-eating” lions of Tsavo.

bonuses.leadin: Recent Arabic works in this genre include Atef Abu Saif's The Drone Eats with Me and Dunya Mikhail's Wave Outside the Sea. For 10 points each:
answers: a diary [accept Bridget Jones's Diary or Zlata's Diary or Diary of a Wave Outside the Sea; prompt on memoir or nonfiction]
The Believer
The Road
parts: Name this genre used to structure Heidi Julavits's The Folded Clock and a popular 1996 novel by Helen Fielding. Zlata Filipović wrote a bestseller in this genre during the Bosnian War.
Mira Jacob's pandemic food diary was published in this literary magazine co-founded by Julavits. Its book publishing offshoot published Nick Hornby's Shakespeare Wrote for Money.
In 2006, The Believer's annual Book Award went to this Cormac McCarthy novel about a father who assures his son that they are "carrying the fire" as "good guys" in a post-apocalyptic America.

bonuses.leadin: Michael Mandelbaum charted this concept's "rise and fall" and also argued against Hungary joining NATO in a 1996 book about its "dawn" in Europe. For 10 points each:
answers: peace [accept democratic peace theory; accept peace on Earth or perpetual peace; accept The Rise and Fall of Peace on Earth or The Dawn of Peace in Europe or "The Flawed Logic of Democratic Peace Theory] (The Doyle clue refers to Kant's idea of perpetual peace.)

economic interdependence between countries [prompt on trade by asking "what is the more general factor that often involves trade?"; accept interdependence theory; accept "Economic Interdependence and War: A Theory of Trade Expectations"]
political liberals [accept neoliberalism]
parts: Name this central concept of an 18th-century theory re-popularized by Michael W. Doyle. Sebastian Rosato critiqued the "flawed logic" of a theory holding that certain governmental dyads maintain this concept.
In democratic peace theory, this factor reduces both systemic and dyadic conflict. Dale C. Copeland argued that related "expectations," not this factor itself, can incentivize avoiding war.
Power and Interdependence authors Robert Keohane and Joseph Nye follow this IR school, contrasted with realism. An often-pejorative term for market-based reforms prefixes this ideology with "neo."

bonuses.leadin: A Punjabi version of this program hosted by Harnarayan Singh has become an unexpected hit, although it had to repurpose Punjabi terms like "tikki" and "chappede" for new uses. For 10 points each:
answers: Hockey Night in Canada [or HNIC]
Pittsburgh Penguins [or Pittsburgh Penguins]
Washington [or WA]
parts: Identify this program whose Punjabi version moved from the CBC to Omni Television in 2013.

Harnarayan Singh's 2016 call of a winning goal by Nick Bonino, then a player for this team, helped the Punjabi edition of Hockey Night in Canada go viral. This team won the 2016 Stanley Cup with Sidney Crosby.

In other news from the Sikh diaspora, Manka Dhingra became the first Sikh elected to state office in the US after a 2017 election in this state. Pramila Jayapal, a US Representative from this state, co-chairs the Congressional Progressive Caucus.

bonuses.leadin: Identify the following about the hot legal trend of the 2010s, granting personhood rights to rivers, for 10 points each.
answers: New Zealand [or Aotearoa]
Ganges River [or Ganga River]
Toledo, Ohio
parts: The first river in the world to gain such a status was in this country. "Dirty dairying" is polluting waterways like the Clutha River in this country, which has an abundant 145 million liters per person of freshwater flow.
The Indian Supreme Court overruled a lower court granting of personhood to the Yamuna River and this other holy river that empties into the Bay of Bengal.

In 2019, this city passed the Lake Erie Bill of Rights that allowed residents to sue polluters on behalf of the lake. This city's excellent Museum of Art owns many examples of glass art, owing to its role as a sheet glass center in the early 20th century.

bonuses.leadin: The Martinos Center collects images of these things with a 3 Tesla scanner. For 10 points each:
answers: neural connections [or connectome or connectomics; accept neural networks; or neural circuitry; accept neural wiring diagram; accept CONNECTOM scanner or Human Connectome Project; prompt on other answers about neurons or anything else related to the nervous system or brains or similar answers; prompt on somatic cells]
consciousness [prompt on minds or perception or cognition or thinking or thoughts or similar]
marmosets [or zaris; or Callithrix; accept Cebuella or Callibella or Mico; prompt on Callitrichidae or Arctopitheci or Hapalidae]
parts: Name these things mapped by an NIH project led by the WU-Minn and MGH/UCLA consortia. Olaf Sporns found a "rich-club organization" formed by hubs of these things, which were first nearly mapped in full for C. elegans in 1986.
The Human Connectome Project provides data about this concept's "neural correlates." Panpsychism suggests that matter generally possesses this mental awareness of experience.

These primates are replacing chimps as a model to study consciousness, social behavior, and aging. Since they are usually born as fraternal twins that exchange stem cells, these New World monkeys are often genetic chimeras.

bonuses.leadin: In 2018, the White House Council of Economic Advisers singled out these businesses for promoting a system that "encourages manufacturers to set artificially high list prices." For 10 points each:
answers: Pharmacy Benefit Managers [or PBMs; do not accept or prompt on "pharmacies," which are different businesses]
Caterpillar Inc. [accept CAT]
Berkshire Hathaway
parts: Identify these companies that negotiate with drug companies to offer favorable prices for products on their formularies. Cigna subsidiary Express Scripts is one of the largest of these companies in the US.
This company stopped employing some PBM services in 2017. The bulldozers and demolition machines that this company makes are mostly painted in its trademark yellow color.
Amazon, JPMorgan Chase, and this third company announced in 2018 that they were forming an independent company to take on employee health care costs. Charlie Munger is its vice chairman.

bonuses.leadin: Until 2014, this software library brought in only about 2,000 dollars per year in donations despite being a critical feature of about two-thirds of all websites on the internet. For 10 points each:
answers: OpenSSL [do not accept or prompt on "SSL" or "OpenSSH"]
JavaScript [or JS; accept Angular.js or Node.js; do not accept or prompt on "Java"]
hash collision [or collision flaw; or collision attack; or hash clash]
parts: Identify this open-source software library used on most HTTPS websites. This software library suffered from the Heartbleed bug.

Another poorly funded but widely used open-source project is the "core" library for this language. Other libraries that build on this popular web scripting language include Angular and Node. It shouldn't be confused with another language widely used to develop Android apps.
Although OpenSSL supports the MD5 hashing algorithm, that algorithm suffers from numerous vulnerabilities, including these flaws in which different inputs produce the same hash value.

bonuses.leadin: Nile Rodgers of Chic was one of the first people to take this kind of song to the top of the charts in the 1980s. For 10 points each:
answers: remixes [or recuts]
Jennifer Lopez [or J.Lo; or Jennifer Lynn Lopez]
The Grey Album (by Danger Mouse)
parts: Identify this type of song that might feature a new rap verse over the original track. Some of these songs may entirely replace the original backing track.
Billboard changed its rules around whether remixes counted towards the chart position of the original song following this artist's re-recording of her hits "I'm Real" and "Ain't It Funny" in 2001.
EMI tried to block the distribution of this 2004 record, whose final track mixed "My 1st Song" into "Helter Skelter."

bonuses.leadin: Alister E. McGrath argued that this title concept was destined for irrelevance in a 2006 book about its "Twilight." For 10 points each:
answers: atheism [accept The Seven Types of Atheism or The Twilight of Atheism or Race in a Godless World: Atheism, Race, and Civilization 1850–1914; prompt on non-belief or secularism or free thought or similar answers]
Richard Dawkins [or Clinton Richard Dawkins]
Bad Religion
parts: Identify this framework with a mixed record on anti-racism that Nathan Alexander traced from 1850 to 1914. John Gray's book on "Seven Types" of this framework identifies Joseph Conrad as promoting the kind that "rejects the idea of progress."
Gray is no fan of this New Atheist, a Nairobi-born biologist who rejected the "God hypothesis" in The God Delusion and explained how complexity could arise without God in The Blind Watchmaker.
Dawkins appeared at the Reason Rally with UCLA professor and Anarchy Evolution author Greg Graffin, who also sang songs like "Sorrow" and "God's Song" as this punk rock band's frontman.

bonuses.leadin: Due to a quirk in this country's transition to democracy, it employs a third of all farmers in the EU. For 10 points each:
answers: România
tractors [prompt on plows]
Czech Republic [or Czechia; or Česká republika; prompt on Czechoslovakia]
parts: Identify this country once billed as "Europe's Granary," whose unproductive agriculture industry includes many farms in its western region, the Banat.

România averages just one of these vehicles per 54 hectares, compared to the EU average of one per 13 hectares. In the US, farmers have pushed for "right to repair" laws that would outlaw John Deere's attempts to lock down the software on these vehicles.

In 2018, the prime minister of this country received millions in EU agricultural subsidies. A multimedia theater popular in this country called laterna magika helped organize its anti-communist movement.

bonuses.leadin: This scholar’s father didn’t trust him to say kaddish for him after he died, providing inspiration for one of his books. For 10 points each:
answers: Stephen Greenblatt (Bracciolini discovered Lucretius's On the Nature of Things.)
Prince Hamlet [do not accept or prompt on "Hamlet's ghost" or "King Hamlet"]
Maggie O'Farrell
parts: Identify this scholar who, in the 2011 book The Swerve, argued that the "world became modern" when Renaissance book hunter Poggio Bracciolini discovered a long-lost Roman manuscript in a monastery.

The aforementioned kaddish anecdote comes from a Greenblatt book about the father of this character "In Purgatory." Mel Gibson weirdly played this character in a 1990 Franco Zeffirelli film where Glenn Close was Queen Gertrude and Alan Bates played King Claudius.

This Irish-British author won the Women's Prize for Fiction for her 2020 novel centering on Shakespeare's son, Hamnet. She also wrote about her childhood struggles with encephalitis in the memoir I Am, I Am, I Am.

bonuses.leadin: In 2004, this county's elections supervisor Brenda Snipes lost track of almost 60,000 ballots. For 10 points each:
answers: Broward County
2000 election (The case was Bush v. Gore.)
Help America Vote Act of 2002 [or HAVA]
parts: Identify this Democratic stronghold whose poorly designed 2018 ballot resulted in about 25,000 undervotes for governor. Fort Lauderdale is its county seat.
Recounts and poor ballot design in another South Florida county, Miami-Dade, were at the center of a weeks-long controversy in this election year that ended in a Supreme Court decision.

This legislation, passed in the aftermath of the 2000 election fiasco, has saddled many states with out-of-date e-voting systems that rely on technology like Zip drives. Robert Ney of Ohio sponsored this bill, whose aim was to replace punch card systems.

bonuses.leadin: Despite scant evidence of its effectiveness, a drug called Makena has been widely prescribed to reduce the risk of someone becoming one of these people. For 10 points each:
answers: premature babies [or preemies; prompt on babies or infants or equivalents]
sickle cell disease [or sickle-cell anemia; prompt on anemia]
Duchenne muscular dystrophy [or MD] (The Love Network is the name for the networks that air The Jerry Lewis MDA Labor Day Telethon.)
parts: Identify these people. Dawn Raffel's recent book The Strange Case of Dr. Couney documents how thousands of these people were saved in the early 20th century by being displayed at Coney Island and other side shows.

Makena was given an expedited review process by the FDA, like this disease’s drug voxelotor. Former NFL safety Ryan Clark suffers from this genetic disease that is common in people from Sub-Saharan Africa.

In 2016, the FDA fast-tracked approval of Exondys 51, which can treat this disease at a cost of 1 million dollars per year. In 2011, an event raising money to fight this disease switched to a benefit concert format to attract more stations to its “Love Network.”

bonuses.leadin: Two crew members at this facility, Taber MacCallum and Jane Poynter, founded space suit company Paragon. For 10 points each:
answers: Biosphere 2 [accept Pushing Our Limits: Insights from Biosphere 2; accept Biospherians; prompt on Biosphere; do not accept or prompt on “Biodome”]
T. C. Boyle [or Thomas Coraghessan Boyle; or T. Coraghessan Boyle]
Colorado [or CO]
parts: Name this Arizona facility depicted in the 2020 documentary Spaceship Earth. During two missions in 1993 and 1994, this facility’s self-sufficient crew lived with over 3,000 types of animal and plant life.
Biosphere 2 inspired this author's 2016 novel The Terranauts. His many other countercultural novels include Outside Looking In, A Friend of the Earth, and The Inner Circle.
T. C. Boyle's novel Drop City is set at a hippie commune in this state, the site of the fictional town of Holt in Kent Haruf's Plainsong. Like Washington, this state legalized marijuana in 2014.

bonuses.leadin: Six large masks made by this artist for her 1976 play Opus Siniestrus were the centerpiece of a 2019 solo show at New York's Norris Gallery. For 10 points each:
answers: Leonora Carrington
Surrealism [or word forms]
Dorothea Tanning [or Dorothea Margaret Tanning]
parts: Identify this artist who died in 2011 at age 94. Her novel The Hearing Trumpet was recently reissued by New York Review Books.

Carrington began associating with members of this art movement in the 1930s. Sensory4 technology was used for the recent "Van Gogh Alive" exhibit at a Florida museum founded by the leading painter of this movement, Salvador Dalí.
This other long-lived Surrealist published the 2001 memoir Between Lives and poetry collections like A Table of Content. Two girls rip wallpaper from the walls in her painting Children's Games.
